Sawaddee ka welcome to hot thai kitchen so this is 
another one of my Thai language for travelers

series so we've covered some basics of Thai 
language and then we looked at phrases that

will be useful in a restaurant setting so in this 
video we're gonna go over some food terms which I

am sure will come in handy when you're eating your 
way through Thailand now if you have seen many of

my videos you probably know some of these words 
by now but we're gonna put them all together let's

get started let's start with proteins because you 
probably run into a situation where you want to

ask whether the mysterious meat is chicken 
or pork or fish or tofu so here we go we're

gonna start with chicken chicken is Kylie not 
to be confused with eggs which is Kylie so here

the difference again DYI is chicken and Kylie is 
eggs now pork is Moo which I know sounds like it

should be beef but it's not because beef is new 
that shrimp is gone now as you can see I've got

various different ways to spell Kong in English 
just so you're aware Thai people try to spell a

Thai word in English and there are many ways that 
we do it so you know all of these are cool fish is

fly now seafood as like a mix of seafood you know 
like a seafood soup or something will be pal a

which means ocean now the full term for seafood is 
a hand Haleh which means ocean food crab is oh now

I need to point out it's a very tight pea it's not 
poo if oh okay it's very important shellfish so we

have a general term for bivalve shellfish like 
oysters and mussels and clams and that is hiyee

hiyee and i almost forgot doc is babe but again 
a very tight pea we've just done meat let's now

look at vegetarian words so vegetarian is Hmong 
so we're at but Hmong Soviet is a very general

term for vegetarian like it's not specifically 
lacto-ovo or anything like that there's another

word day and if you're vegan you might want to go 
with this one day is actually stricter than vegan

so no animal products plus a few other rules so 
if you want to really make sure just say giving

day like point to yourself and say giving day 
and that means I eat day and you be sure to not

have any animal products so tofu is Soho and 
vegetables just vegetables in general its pop

now if you listen to that the last letter of that 
word puck is a K but I'm not releasing the the K

sound at the end so it's not puck so in Thailand 
in Thai language we don't do that so it's packed

and then stop yourself this one is important 
peanuts because a lot of people are allergic to

peanuts and nuts in general so the general term 
for nuts is - ah - ah which means both nuts and

legumes actually so if you want to spot specify 
peanuts you want to say - Ellie song - Ally song

because if you get a papaya salad for example 
there's both long beans and peanuts and both of

them can be referred to as to us so you want to 
specify what kind of Toa and cashews this is a

little hard but MITM among him upon met Mamoon 
him upon if you just stop at MIT mamoon they

will know what you're talking about we generally 
don't do almonds or any other nuts in our cuisine

so those are the two that you need to be concerned 
about spicy terms this is gonna come in handy so

Chili's is free now spicy is PIP but if you want 
to ask them to make your food very spicy you want

to say pip pip you say it twice guaranteed to be 
spicy now if you want it the opposite you want it

a little bit spicy you use the word knit knowing 
which means a little bit so pet midni is a little

bit spicy and if you want not spicy at all for my 
previous videos you might know that the word not

is mine so you would say my pip my pit know that 
the position of the adjective changes depending on

what it is pit knit know but it's my pit just 
so you know let's talk some drinks so just so

you know the word nom means water or it refers 
to anything that's a liquid okay that's a good

term to know in general so plain water is ma'am 
plow ice is nam kang which literally means hard

water you want coffee you ask for gough air 
tea is cha or you can also say numb cha and

if you want a beer you just say beer let's take a 
look at some cooking techniques because that will

indicate what kind of food you're talking about 
so pot is a stir-fry umm refers to soups gang is

curry noon is when something is steamed taut is 
deep-fried ping is to grill but usually there's

small things like on a skewer or something like 
that if there are bigger things on the grill we

use the word yang for grill now that you have all 
these food vocabularies I'm gonna teach you two

more words that are very useful and that is to ask 
for something and to ask for something to not be

added to your food so to ask for something you 
want to use the word kaw kaw means like please

give me kind of situation so if you want to ask 
for ice you say car num Kang Chi you want to add

your polite suffix at the end or for example if 
you want to ask for water you can say car nam POW

cup right and now if you want something to not be 
added to your food say you don't need eggs you're

vegetarian you do want to make sure they don't add 
any eggs in it you can see my site my is not size

to add so my site followed by whatever the item is 
my site chi my site pray my Sai Gon maybe you're

allergic to shrimp you say my site cool this is 
a very important when I have lots of people ask

me about this how do you say I am allergic to 
something allergic is pat pat and to say I'm

allergic you just put I in front of the word Pat 
so I we've talked about this depending on whether

you're a man or a woman it could be tan Pat or 
palm Pat followed by the item you're allergic to

I would suggest that you have a piece of paper 
with Thai writing on it that says I'm allergic

to whatever in fact I will write that down and 
I will put it on my website so you can copy and

paste if you want now keep in mind that I don't 
know what you're allergic to so I'm just gonna
